pages.title: Exercise 1: Watch and Learn
pages.description:
Welcome to your first exercise!

Before we start building anything, it's important to understand how the game works. In this step, you'll play the Snake game and observe its behavior. Think like a game designer or detective: what rules control the game? What happens when the snake eats something? How does the snake move? What causes the game to end?

Use the text field on the left to write down all the rules and patterns you notice. There are no wrong answers — this is about observation and curiosity.

Once you're done, click the Save button to continue to the next part of the workshop, where we’ll start designing and tweaking the game together!

pages.title: Exercise 2: Design Your Level
pages.description:
Awesome! Now that you understand the game rules, it's time to shape the game world yourself.

In this exercise, you'll define a custom obstacle layout using a simple text configuration format. This layout will determine where the snake can move — and where it can’t!

Your configuration should follow this format:

#rows,#columns
%unoccupied cell symbol%,%obstacle symbol%
%obstacles map goes here%

Example:

10,10
0,X
0000000000
00X0000000
0000000000
0000XXX000
0000000000
00X0000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000

Legend:

  • 0 = empty space (the snake can move here)
  • X = obstacle (the snake cannot move here)

Make sure:

  • The number of rows and columns matches your actual map layout.
  • Every row contains exactly the number of columns you specified.
  • You experiment with different obstacle placements to create fun or tricky paths!

When you're done, click Save to try it out and continue to the next part.
